title: Sociology 106: Quantitative Sociological Methods
text:
Sociology 106 is…
…an intermediate undergraduate social science research methods course. It will emphasize the motivation, computation, and interpretation of statistical tests for one or two continuous or categorical variables. The course will also train students in the use of the R statistical programming language for data management and analysis.

title: Sociology 106: Quantitative Sociological Methods
text:
Sociology 106 is not…
…about math. Statistics is about adjudicating between rival explanations of phenomena about a population, using data from that population.

This course can be taught with more of a focus on the math / statistical theory or with more of a focus on sociological applications
We will be more applied, still with some math

…about the “one true way to answer sociological questions”.

title: Sociology 106: Quantitative Sociological Methods
section: For this course, we will assume:
text:
For this course, we will assume:

Social categories and phenomena can be usefully represented using numbers.
Variables measure what they purport to measure.
All samples are good samples.

title: Sociology 106: Quantitative Sociological Methods
section: After completing Sociology 106, you will be able to:
text:
After completing Sociology 106, you will be able to:

Understand the basic logic of statistical inference.
Identify the appropriate statistical test given a specific type of data.
Compute descriptive statistics, graphs, tables, and simple statistical tests using R.
Interpret the results of statistical tests and discuss their relevance to a particular research question.

Keys to Success in Sociology 106
Learning statistics is like learning a language

The material in this course can be challenging / counterintuitive if you haven’t seen it before
It is important not to be intimidated by new terms or the use of letters to represent quantities or variables
Review your algebra skills if necessary

Lecture slides will be made available, but are not a substitute for careful note taking
